column1: Guadalajara ( GWAH-də-lə-HAR-ə
column2: Spanish: [ɡwaðalaˈxaɾa] (listen)) is a metropolis in western Mexico and the capital of the state of Jalisco. The city has a population of 1
column5: while the Guadalajara metropolitan area has a population of 5
column8: making it the second-largest metropolitan area in the country. Guadalajara has the second highest population density in Mexico
column10: 361 people per square kilometre. Guadalajara is an international center of business
column11: finance
column13: and culture
column14: as well as the economic center of the Bajío region
column15: one of the most productive and developed regions in Latin America.Guadalajara is the tenth largest metropolitan area in Latin America and a major Latin American tech hub and financial center. It is one of the most productive and globally competitive cities in the world. The city is an important center for science
column22: and tourism in Mexico. It is home to numerous landmarks
column27: and the San Juan de Dios Market—the largest indoor market in Latin America.Guadalajara was founded on 14 February 1542 by Cristóbal de Oñate
column29: as the capital of the Kingdom of Nueva Galicia
column30: part of the Viceroyalty of New Spain. After 1572
column33: became the only authority in New Spain with autonomy over Nueva Galicia
column34: owing to rapidly growing wealth in the kingdom following the discovery of silver. By the 18th century
column35: Guadalajara had taken its place as Mexico's second largest city
column36: following mass colonial migrations in the 1720s and 1760s. During the Mexican War of Independence
column37: independence leader Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla established Mexico's first revolutionary government in Guadalajara in 1810. The city flourished during the Porfiriato
column38: with the advent of the industrial revolution
column39: but its growth was hampered significantly during the Mexican Revolution. In 1929
column40: the Cristero War ended within the confines of the city
column41: when President Plutarco Elías Calles proclaimed the Grito de Guadalajara. The city saw continuous growth throughout the rest of the 20th century
column42: attaining a 1 million metro population in the 1960s and passing 3 million in the 1990s.

column1: Guadalajara is a global city and one of Mexico's most important cultural centers. It is home to numerous mainstays of Mexican culture

column3: Tequila
column4: and Birria and hosts numerous notable events
column5: including the Guadalajara International Film Festival
column6: the most important film festival in Latin America
column7: and the Guadalajara International Book Fair
column8: the largest book fair in the Americas. The city was the American Capital of Culture in 2005 and has hosted numerous global events
column11: the 1st Ibero-American Summit in 1991
column12: and the 2011 Pan American Games. The city is home to numerous universities and research institutions
column13: including the University of Guadalajara and the Universidad Autónoma de Guadalajara
column14: two of the highest-ranked universities in Mexico and Latin America.

column1: == Etymology ==
The conquistador
column2: Cristóbal de Oñate
column3: named the city in honor of the conqueror of western Mexico
column4: Nuño de Guzmán
column5: who was born in Guadalajara
column6: Spain. The name comes from the Arabic وادي الحجارة (wādī al-ḥajārah)
column7: which means 'Valley of the Stone'
column8: or 'Fortress Valley'.

column1: == History ==
=== Pre-Hispanic Era ===
Unlike the surrounding areas
column2: the central Atemajac Valley
column3: where Guadalajara is located
column4: contained no human settlements. To the east of the Atemajac Valley were the Tonallan and Tetlán peoples. At the extremes were the Zapopan
column5: Atemajac
column6: Zoquipan
column7: Thesistan
column8: Coyula

column3: Analco and Mexicaltzingo were annexed to the Atemajac site in 1669.

column1: === Foundation ===
Guadalajara was originally founded at three other sites before moving to its current location. The first settlement in 1532 was in Mesa del Cerro
column2: now known as Nochistlán
column3: Zacatecas. This site was settled by Cristóbal de Oñate as commissioned by Nuño de Guzmán
column4: with the purpose of securing recent conquests and defending them from the still-hostile natives. This settlement did not last long due to its lack of usable water sources. In 1533 it was moved to a site near Tonalá. Four years later
column5: Guzmán ordered that the village be moved to Tlacotán. During this time
column6: the Spanish king Charles I granted the city the coat of arms which it retains to this day.During the Mixtón War
column7: settlers were attacked by the Caxcan
column8: Portecuex
column9: and Zacateco peoples under the command of Tenamaxtli. The war was initiated in response to the cruel treatment of indigenous peoples by Nuño de Guzmán
column10: in particular the enslavement of captured natives. After multiple defeats
column11: Viceroy Antonio de Mendoza took control of the Spanish campaign to suppress the revolt. The conflict ended after Mendoza made concessions such as freeing Indian slaves and granting amnesty. The village of Guadalajara barely survived the war
column12: and the villagers attributed their survival to the Archangel Michael
column13: who remains the patron of the city to this day.

column1: After the war
column2: the city was moved once again—this time to a more defensible location. This final relocation would prove permanent. In 1542
column3: records indicate that 126 people were living in Guadalajara. That same year
column4: it was granted cityhood by the king of Spain. Guadalajara was officially founded on February 14
column5: 1542 in the Atemajac Valley. The settlement was named for Nuño de Guzmán's Spanish hometown.In 1559
column6: royal and bishopric offices for the province of Nueva Galicia were moved from Compostela to Guadalajara and
column8: Guadalajara became the province's new capital. Construction of the cathedral began in 1563. In 1575
column9: religious orders such as the Augustinians and Dominicans arrived
column10: eventually making the city a center for evangelization efforts.While capital of the Kingdom of Nueva Galicia
column11: the city's inhabitants achieved a high standard of living
column13: agriculture

column1: The Guadalajara of the sixteenth century was a rather small and often overlooked community. It was mainly frequented by traveling merchants. Several epidemics drastically reduced the city's indigenous population
column2: leading to the construction of its first hospital in 1557.
the University of Guadalajara was established. The dedication was held in 1792 at the site of the old Santo Tomas College. While the institution was founded during the 18th century
column3: it would not be fully developed until the 20th century
column4: starting in 1925. In 1794
column5: the Hospital Real de San Miguel de Belén
column6: or simply the Hospital de Belén
column7: was opened.Guadalajara's economy during the 18th century was based on agriculture and the production of non-durable goods such as textiles
column8: shoes and food products.Despite epidemics
column11: Guadalajara would become one of the most important population centers in New Spain.

column1: === Independence ===
Guadalajara remained the capital of Nueva Galicia with some modifications until the Mexican War of Independence. Miguel Hidalgo entered San Pedro (now Tlaquepaque) on November 25
column2: 1810 and the next day he was greeted effusively in Guadalajara. The city's workers had experienced poor living conditions and were swayed by promises of lower taxes and the abolition of slavery. Despite a soured welcome
column3: due to the rebel army's violence toward city residents
column4: especially royalists
column5: Hidalgo kept his promise and
column6: on December 6
column8: slavery was abolished in Guadalajara
column9: a proclamation which has been honored since the end of the war. During this time
column10: he founded the newspaper El Despertador Americano
column11: dedicated to the insurgent cause.Royalist forces marched to Guadalajara
column13: 000 men. Insurgents Ignacio Allende and Mariano Abasolo wanted to concentrate their forces in the city and plan an escape route should they be defeated
column14: but Hidalgo rejected this idea. Their second choice was to make a stand at the Puente de Calderon just outside the city. Hidalgo had between 80
column18: decimating the insurgent army and forcing Hidalgo to flee toward Aguascalientes. Guadalajara remained in royalist hands until near the end of the war.'

column1: On January 17
column3: the insurgent army was again defeated on the outskirts of Guadalajara in the Battle of Calderón Bridge.

column1: New Galicia
column2: now Jalisco
column3: adhered to the Plan de Iguala on June 13

column2: Guadalajara became capital of the newly founded state of Jalisco. In 1844
column3: General Mariano Paredes y Arrillaga initiated a revolt against the government of President Antonio López de Santa Anna. Santa Anna personally ensured that the revolt was quelled. However
column4: while Santa Anna was in Guadalajara
column5: a revolt called the Three Hour Revolution brought José Joaquín Herrera to the presidency and put Santa Anna into exile.President Benito Juárez made Guadalajara the seat of his government in 1856
column6: during the Reform War. French troops entered the city during the French Intervention in 1864
column7: and it was retaken by Mexican troops in 1866.Despite the violence

column9: technological and social growth for the city. After Independence

Rail lines connecting the city to the Pacific coast and north to the United States intensified trade and allowed the shipment of products from rural areas of Jalisco. column1: === 20th century ===
Throughout the twentieth century
column2: seeing growth in its industrial
column3: tourist and service industries
column4: Guadalajara began a period of rapid transformation into the metropolis it is today. The city would gain the second largest economy in Mexico
column5: following only by Mexico City. After the Mexican Revolution of 1910
column6: Guadalajara became the second most populous city in the country. However
column7: the decades that followed brought a number of regional wars in the states of Jalisco
column8: Michoacán
column9: and Guanajuato. The aftermath of the Great Depression took further toll on the city. Fortunately
column10: by the 1940s the city would experience industrial
column11: demographic

column2: the Mexican Revolution began
column3: bringing an end to the Porfiriato. With conflict concentrated in the capital
column4: Guadalajara experienced relative calm. After the Cristero Conflict
column5: peace returned to Guadalajara and the city flourished
column6: outgrowing its colonial roots. This period saw the birth of new schools of architecture that would decorate the city from the 1920s to the 1980s.

column1: Guadalajara again experienced substantial growth after the 1930s
column2: and the first industrial park was established in 1947. Its population surpassed one million in 1964
column3: and by the 1970s it was Mexico's second-largest city and the largest in western Mexico. Most of the modern city's urbanization took place between the 1940s and the 1980s
column4: with the population doubling every ten years until it stood at 2.5 million in 1980. The population of the municipality has stagnated
column5: and even declined
column6: slowly but steadily
column7: since the early 1990s.The increase in population brought with it an increase in the size of what is now called Greater Guadalajara
column8: rather than an increase in the population density of the city. Migrants coming into Guadalajara from the 1940s to the 1980s were mostly from rural areas and lived in the city center until they had enough money to buy property. This property was generally bought in the edges of the city
column11: it was described as a "divided city" east to west based on socioeconomic class. Since then
column12: the city has evolved into four sectors
column13: which are still more or less class-centered. The upper classes tend to live in Hidalgo and Juárez in the northwest and southwest
column14: while lower classes tend to live in the city center
column15: Libertad in the northeast and southeast in Reforma. However
column16: lower class development has developed on the city's periphery and upper and middle classes are migrating toward Zapopan
column17: making the situation less neatly divided.

column1: Since 1996
column2: the activity of multinational corporations has had a significant effect on the economic and social development of the city. The presence of companies such as Kodak
column3: Hewlett-Packard
column4: Motorola and IBM has been based on production facilities built outside the city proper
column5: bringing in foreign labor and capital. This was made possible in the 1980s by surplus labor
column6: infrastructure improvements and government incentives. These companies focus on electrical and electronic items
column7: which is now one of Guadalajara's two main products (the other being beer). This has internationalized the economy
column8: steering it away from manufacturing and toward services
column9: dependent on technology and foreign investment. This has not been favorable for the unskilled working class and traditional labor sectors.

column1: The 1992 Guadalajara explosions occurred on April 22
column3: when gasoline explosions in the sewer system over four hours destroyed 8 km (5 mi) of streets in the downtown district of Analco. Gante Street was the most damaged. Officially
column4: 206 people were killed
column5: nearly 500 injured and 15
column6: 000 were left homeless. The estimated monetary damage ranges between $300 million and $1 billion. The affected areas can be recognized by their more modern architecture.Three days before the explosion
column7: residents started complaining of a strong gasoline-like smell coming from the sewers. City workers were dispatched to check the sewers and found dangerously high levels of gasoline fumes. However
column8: no evacuations were ordered. An investigation into the disaster found that there were two precipitating causes. The first was new water pipes that were built too close to an existing gasoline pipeline. Chemical reactions between the pipes caused erosion. The second was a flaw in the sewer design that did not allow accumulated gases to escape.Arrests were made to indict those responsible for the blasts. Four officials of Pemex (the state oil company) were indicted and charged on the basis of negligence. Ultimately
column10: these people were cleared of all charges. Calls for the restructuring of PEMEX were made but they were successfully resisted.The 1990s were marked by events such as the explosions of April 22
column13: and the murder of the Cardinal Juan Jesús Posadas Ocampo in 1993. The 1992 explosions caused massive infrastructure damage to hundreds of houses
column16: and businesses in the Analco colony
column17: "without a clear delineator of information and responsibilities to date
column18:
in one of the most tragic events in the history of Guadalajara. The investigation of the facts lasted more than 11 years in which insufficient evidence was found to appoint a manager, investigations are now closed attributing the events to an accident. This event, in addition to Mexico's 1994 economic crisis, resulted in the loss of Guadalajara's industrial power.


=== Modern era ===

The city has hosted numerous important international events, such as the first Cumbre Iberoamericana in 1991; the Third Summit of Heads of State and Governments of Latin America, the Caribbean and the European Union in 2004; the Encuentro Internacional de Promotores y Gestores Culturales in 2005; and the 2011 Pan American Games. It was named the American Capital of Culture in 2005 and the Ciudad Educadora (Educator City). in 2006. It was recognized as Mexico's first Smart City due to its use of developing technology. 
During each government period, the city went through structural plans with which new areas and commercial hubs were born and with which transnational corporations and international industries arrived in the city. The city housed the first shopping malls in Mexico. 
The city expanded rapidly before merging with the Zapopan municipality. Among the developments created during this period were the Guadalajara Expo, the light rail, shopping centers, the expansion of streets and avenues, and the birth and development of road infrastructure, services, tourism, industrial, etc. The first shopping center in Latin America emerged in the city, the first urban electric-train system in Latin America, and the first autonomous university in Mexico.A 2007 survey entitled Cities of the Future"
column19: FDi magazine ranked Guadalajara first among major Mexican cities and second among major North American cities in terms of economic potential
column20: behind Chicago. The magazine also rated it as the most business-friendly Latin American city in 2007.

column1: == Geography ==
=== Climate ===
Under the Köppen climate classification
column2: Guadalajara has a humid subtropical climate (Cwa) that is quite close to a tropical climate
column3: featuring dry
column4: warm winters and hot
column5: wet summers. Guadalajara's climate is influenced by its high altitude and the general seasonality of precipitation patterns in western North America.

column1: Although the temperature is warm year-round
column2: Guadalajara has very strong seasonal variation in precipitation. The northward movement of the Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone brings a great deal of rain in the summer months
column3: whereas
column4: for the rest of the year
column5: the climate is rather dry. The extra moisture in the wet months moderates the temperatures
column6: resulting in cooler days and nights during this period. The highest temperatures are usually reached in May averaging 33 °C (91 °F)
column7: but can reach up to 37 °C (99 °F) just before the onset of monsoon season. March tends to be the driest month and July the wettest
column8: with an average of 273 millimetres (10.7 in) of rain
column9: over a quarter of the annual average of about 1

column1: During the summer
column2: afternoon storms are very common and can sometimes bring hail flurries to the city
column3: especially toward late August or September. Winters are relatively warm despite the city's altitude
column4: with January daytime temperatures reaching about 25 °C (77 °F) and nighttime temperatures about 10 °C (50 °F). However
column5: the outskirts of the city (generally those close to the Primavera Forest) experience on average cooler temperatures than the city itself. There
column6: temperatures around 0 °C (32 °F) can be recorded during the coldest nights. Frost may also occur during the coldest nights
column7: but temperatures rarely fall below 0 °C (32 °F) in the city
column8: making it an uncommon phenomenon. Cold fronts in winter can sometimes bring light rain to the city for several days in a row. Snowfall is extraordinarily rare
column9: with the last recorded one occurring in December 1997
column10: which was the first time in 116 years
column11: as it had previously last fallen in 1881.

column1: === Topography ===
Guadalajara's natural wealth is represented by the La Primavera Forest
column2: Los Colomos
column3: and the Barranca de Huentitán. The flora in these areas includes michoacan pines
column4: several species of oak
column5: sweetgum
column6: ash
column7: willow
column8: and introduced trees such as poincianas
column9: jacarandas and ficus.  It also includes orchids
column10: roses and various species of fungi. The fauna includes typical urban fauna in addition to 106 species of mammals
column11: 19 species of reptiles and six species of fish.La Barranca de Huentitán (the Huentitán Forest) (also known as Barranca de Oblatos and Barranca de Oblatos-Huentitán) is a National Park located just north of the municipality of Guadalajara. The barranca (canyon) borders two colonias (neighborhoods) of the city

column1: It covers approximately 1
column2: 136 hectares
column3: and varies 600 meters in altitude. The funicular railway in the park starts at 1000 meters above sea level and rises to 1520 meters above sea level. In the 16th century
column4: during the Spanish Conquest
column5: the Huentitán area including the canyon was the site of battles between local Indian populations and the Spanish.  Later
column6: it was the site of battles between different factions during the Mexican Revolution and the Cristero Rebellion.

column1: The canyon is a biogeographic corridor which is home to four types of vegetation: deciduous tropical forest
column2: gallery forest
column3: heath vegetation and secondary vegetation. In addition to introduced species
column4: there are many native species of flora and fauna. The canyon is studied by national and international researchers as it contains great biological diversity due to its geographical location.

column1: On June 5
column2: 1997 it was declared a Protected Natural Area
column3: as an Area Subject to Ecological Conservation (Zona Sujeta a Conservación Ecológica).

column1: === Urbanism ===
Guadalajara's street plan has evolved over time into a radial urban plan
column2: with five major routes into and out of the city.  It is surrounded by ring roads.

column1: The original city of Guadalajara was planned on a grid
column2: with north-south and east-west intersecting streets.

column1: Over time
column2: villages surrounding Guadalajara were incorporated into the city - first Analco to the southeast
column3: then Mexicaltzingo to the south
column4: Mezquitan to the north and San Juan de Dios to the east
column5: all of which introduced more variety to the plan.  As it grew towards the west
column6: it kept the original north-south orientation.  As it grew towards the east
column7: this grid was tilted towards the south-east to match up with the grids of the former towns Analco and San Juan de Dios
column8: across the river from central Guadalajara on the eastern side of Rio San Juan de Dios (Rio San Juan de Dios is now underground; it runs beneath Calzada Independencia).

column1: When the railway was introduced to Guadalajara in 1888
column2: the southern part of the city began development
column3: and its streets aligned with the grid to the east of the old Rio San Juan de Dios.  Additional 20th century expansion of the city introduced even more variety
column4: as developers introduced different kinds of non-grid street plans in new areas.

column1: During the government of José de Jesús González Gallo
column2: between 1947 and 1953
column3: major public works changed the urban landscape of the historic center of the city.

column1: Major controversial projects included the widening of Avenida 16 de Septiembre and Avenida Juárez
column2: which were no longer adequate to handle car traffic in the center of the city. In the process
column3: many buildings of architectural and historical value were demolished. Historical buildings around Guadalajara Cathedral were also demolished to leave large open spaces on the four sides of the Cathedral in the form of a large Latin cross
column4: in which the Cathedral is now centered.  There were other
column5: somewhat less controversial
column6: projects to improve the flow of traffic and increase commerce in other parts of the city.

== Economy ==

Guadalajara has the third-largest economy and industrial infrastructure in Mexico and contributes 37% of the state of Jalisco's total gross production. Its economic base is strong and well diversified
column2: mainly based on commerce and services
column3: although the manufacturing sector plays a defining role. It is ranked in the top ten in Latin America in gross domestic product and the third highest ranking in Mexico.

column1: In its 2007 survey entitled "Cities of the Future"
column2: FDi magazine ranked Guadalajara highest among major Mexican cities and designated Guadalajara as having the second strongest economic potential of any major North American city behind Chicago. FDI ranked it as the most business-friendly Latin American city in 2007.In 2009 Moody's Investors Service assigned ratings of Ba1 (Global scale
column3: local currency) and A1.mx (Mexican national scale). During the prior five years
column4: the municipality's financial performance had been mixed but had begun to stabilize in the later two years. Guadalajara manages one of the largest budgets among Mexican municipalities and its revenue per capita indicator (Ps. $2
column5: 265) places it above the average for Moody's-rated municipalities in Mexico.The city's economy has two main sectors. Commerce and tourism employ most: about 60% of the population. The other is industry
column6: which has been the engine of economic growth and the basis of Guadalajara's economic importance nationally even though it employs only about a third of the population. Industries here produce products such as food and beverages
column7: toys
column8: textiles
column11: pharmaceuticals
column13: furniture and steel products.Two of the major industries have been textiles and shoes
column14: which are still dynamic and growing. Sixty percent of manufactured products are sold domestically
column16: mostly to the United States. This makes Guadalajara's economic fortunes dependent on those of the U.S.
column17: both as a source of investment and as a market for its goods.In 2007
column18: fDi magazine stated that Guadalajara has the second strongest economic potential of any major North American city
column19: behind only Chicago. The same research noted Guadalajara as a "city of the future" due to its youthful population
column20: low unemployment and large number of recent foreign investment deals; it was found to be the third most business-friendly city in North America.The city has to compete with China
column21: especially for electronics industries which rely on high volume and low wages. This has caused the it to move toward high-mix
column24: its traditional advantage of proximity to the U.S. market is one reason Guadalajara stays competitive. Mexico ranked third in 2009 in Latin America for the export of information technology services
column25: behind Brazil and Argentina. This kind of service is mostly related to online and telephone technical support. The major challenge this sector has is the lack of university graduates who speak English.

column1: === Industries ===
Most of the economy revolves around commerce
column2: employing 60% of the population. This activity has mainly focused on the purchase and sale of the following products: food and beverages
column3: textiles
column4: electronic appliances
column5: tobacco
column6: cosmetics
column7: sport articles
column8: construction materials and others. Guadalajara's commercial activity is second only to Mexico City.

column1: Globalization and neoliberal reforms have affected the form and distribution of commerce in Guadalajara since the early 1990s. This has led to tensions between traditional markets
column2: such as the Mercardo Libertad
column3: and retailers such as department stores and supermarkets. Local governments in the metropolitan area used to invest in and heavily regulate traditional markets but this is no longer the case. To attract private corporate investment
column4: regulatory control eased and most commercial developments now are controlled by private concerns.

column1: A large segment of the commercial sector caters to tourists and other visitors. Recreational tourism is mainly concentrated in the historic downtown. In addition to being a cultural and recreational attraction and thanks to its privileged geographical location

column1: === Foreign trade ===

Most of Guadalajara's economic growth since 1990 has been tied with foreign investment. International firms have invested here to take advantage of the relatively cheap but educated and highly productive labor
column2: establishing manufacturing plants that re-export their products to the United States
column3: as well as provide goods for the internal Mexican market.A media report in early October 2013 stated that five major Indian IT (information technology) companies have established offices in Guadalajara
column4: while several other Indian IT companies continue to explore the option of expanding to Mexico. Due to the competitiveness in the Indian IT sector
column5: companies are expanding internationally and Mexico offers an affordable opportunity for Indian companies to better position themselves to enter the United States market. The trend emerged after 2006 and the Mexican government offers incentives to foreign companies.Exports from the city went from US$3.92 billion in 1995 to 14.3 billion in 2003. From 1990 to 2000
column6: socio-economic indicators show that quality of life improved overall; however
column7: there is still a large gap between the rich and the poor
column8: and the rich have benefited from the globalization and privatization of the economy more than the poor.International investment has affected the labor market in the metro area and that of the rural towns and villages that surround it. Guadalajara is the distribution center for the region and its demands have led to a shifting of employment
column9: from traditional agriculture and crafts to manufacturing and commerce in urban centers. This has led to mass migration from the rural areas to the metropolitan area.

Some of the libraries also have a physical enclosure – among them the historic Octavio Paz Ibero-American Library of the University of Guadalajara and the Public Library of the State of Jalisco located in the adjoining city of Zapopan – with options for querying digital information over the Internet.

column1: === Architecture ===

The style of architecture prevalent in Europe during the founding of Guadalajara is paralleled in the city's colonial buildings. The Metropolitan Cathedral and Teatro Degollado are the purest examples of neoclassical architecture. The historical center hosts religious and civil colonial buildings
column2: which are noted for their architectural and historical significance and are a rich mix of styles which are rooted in indigenous cultural contributions (mainly from Ute origin)
column3: incorporated in the Mozarabic and castizo
column4: and later in modern European influences (mainly French and Italian) and American (specifically
column5: from the United States).

column1: === Festivals ===

Guadalajara is also known for several large cultural festivals. The International Film Festival of Guadalajara is a yearly event which happens in March. column1: === Landmarks ===
The historic downtown of Guadalajara is the oldest section of the city
column2: where it was founded and where the oldest buildings are. It centers on Paseo Morelos/Paseo Hospicio from the Plaza de Armas
column3: where the seats of ecclesiastical and secular power are
column4: east toward the Plaza de Mariachis and the Hospicio Cabañas. The Plaza de Armas is a rectangular plaza with gardens
column5: ironwork benches and an ironwork kiosk which was made in Paris in the 19th century.

column1: Landmarks and monuments of Guadalajara
Within Guadalajara's historic downtown
column2: there are many squares and public parks: Parque Morelos
column3: Plaza de los Mariachis
column4: Plaza Fundadores
column5: Plaza Tapatia
column6: Plaza del Agave
column7: Parque Revolucion
column8: Jardin del Santuario
column11: Plaza Guadalajara and the Rotonda de los Hombres Ilustres
column12: the last four of which surround the cathedral to form a Latin Cross.Construction began on the Metropolitan Cathedral in 1558 and the church was consecrated in 1616. Its two towers were built in the 19th century after an earthquake destroyed the originals. They are considered one of the city's symbols. The architecture is a mix of Gothic
column13: Baroque
column14: Moorish and Neoclassical. The interior has three naves and eleven side altars
column15: covered by a roof supported by 30 Doric columns.

column1: The Rotonda de los Hombres Ilustres (Rotunda of Illustrious Men) is a monument made of quarried stone
column2: built in 1952 to honor the memory of distinguished people from Jalisco. A circular structure of 17 columns surrounds 98 urns containing the remains of those honored. Across the street is the municipal palace which was built in 1952. It has four façades of quarried stone. It is mostly of Neoclassical design with elements such as courtyards
column3: entrances and columns that imitate the older structures of the city.The Palace of the State Government is in Churrigueresque and Neoclassical styles and was begun in the 17th century and finished in 1774. The interior was completely remodeled after an explosion in 1859. This building contains murals by José Clemente Orozco
column4: a native of Jalisco
column5: including "Lucha Social"
column6: "Circo Político"
column7: "Las Fuerzas Ocultas" and "Hidalgo" which depicts Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla with his arm raised above his head in anger at the government and the church.The Cathedral is bordered to the east by the Plaza de la Liberación
column8: nicknamed the Plaza de las Dos Copas
column9: referring to the two fountains on the east and west sides. Facing this plaza is the Teatro Degollado (Degollado Theater). It was built in the mid-nineteenth century in Neoclassical design. The main portal has a pediment with a scene in relief called "Apollo and the Muses" sculpted in marble by Benito Castañeda. The interior vaulted ceiling is painted with a fresco by Jacobo Gálvez and Gerardo Suárez which depicts a scene from the Divine Comedy. Behind the theater is another plaza with a fountain called the Fuente de los Fundadores (Fountain of the Founders). The plaza is in the exact spot where the city was founded and contains a sculpture depicting Cristobal de Oñate at the event (finsemana).Between the Cathedral and the Hospicio is the large Plaza Tapatía which covers 70
column10: 000 m2. Its centerpiece is the large Quetzalcoátl sculpture/fountain. Southeast of this plaza is the Mercado Libertad
column11: also called the Mercado de San Juan de Dios
column12: one of the largest traditional markets in Mexico. The Temple of San Juan de Dios
column13: a Baroque church built in the 17th century

column1: At the far east end is the Plaza de los Mariachis and the Ex-Hospicio Cabañas. The Plaza de los Mariachis is faced by restaurants where one can hear live mariachis play
column2: especially at night. The Ex-Hospicio Cabañas extends along the entire east side of the Plaza. This building was constructed by Manuel Tolsá beginning in 1805 under orders of Carlos III. It was inaugurated and began its function as an orphanage in 1810
column3: in spite of the fact that it would not be finished until 1845. It was named after Bishop Ruiz de Cabañas y Crespo. The façade is Neoclassical and its main entrance is topped by a triangular pediment. Today
column4: it is the home of the Instituto Cultural Cabañas (Cabañas Cultural Institute) and its main attraction is the murals by José Clemente Orozco
column5: which cover the main entrance hall. Among these murals is "Hombre del Fuego" (Man of Fire)
column6: considered to be one of Orozco's finest works.Off this east–west axis are other significant constructions. The Legislative Place is Neoclassical and was originally built in the 18th century. It was reconstructed in 1982. The Palace of Justice was finished in 1897. The Old University Building was a Jesuit college named Santo Tomás de Aquino. It was founded in 1591. It became the second Mexican University in 1792. Its main portal is of yellow stone. The Casa de los Perros (House of the Dogs) was constructed in 1896 in Neoclassical design. On Avenida Juarez is the Sanctuary of Nuestra Señora del Carmen which was founded between 1687 and 1690 and remodeled completely in 1830. It retains its original coat of arms of the Carmelite Order as well as sculptures of the prophets Elijah and Elisha. Adjoining it is what is left of the Carmelite monastery
column7: which was one of the richest in New Spain.

column1: === Music ===
Mariachi music is strongly associated with Guadalajara both in Mexico and abroad even though the musical style originated in the nearby town of Cocula
column2: Jalisco. The connection between the city and mariachi began in 1907 when an eight-piece mariachi band and four dancers from the city performed on stage at the president's residence for both Porfirio Díaz and the Secretary of State of the United States. This made the music a symbol of west Mexico
column3: and after the migration of many people from the Guadalajara area to Mexico City (mostly settling near Plaza Garibaldi)
column4: it then became a symbol of Mexican identity as wellGuadalajara hosts the Festival of Mariachi and Charreria
column5: which began in 1994. It attracts people in the fields of art
column6: culture and politics from Mexico and abroad. Regularly the best mariachis in Mexico participate
column7: such as Mariachi Vargas
column8: Mariachi de América and Mariachi los Camperos de Nati Cano. Mariachi bands from all over the world participate
column9: coming from countries such as Venezuela
column11: Belgium
column13: France

column1: The events of this festival take place in venues all over the metropolitan area
column2: and include a parade with floats. In August 2009
column3: 542 mariachi musicians played together for a little over ten minutes to break the world record for largest mariachi group. The musicians played various songs ending with two classic Mexican songs "Cielito Lindo" and "Guadalajara". The feat was performed during the XVI Encuentro Internacional del Mariachi y la Charreria. The prior record was 520 musicians in 2007 in San Antonio
column4: Texas.In the historic center of the city is the Plaza de los Mariachis
column5: named such as many groups play here. The plaza was renovated for the 2011 Pan American Games in anticipation of the crowds visiting. Over 750 mariachi musicians play traditional melodies on the plaza
column6: and along with the restaurants and other businesses
column7: the plaza supports more than 830 families.

column1: A recent innovation has been the fusion of mariachi melodies and instruments with rock and roll performed by rock musicians in the Guadalajara area. An album collecting a number of these melodies was produced called "Mariachi Rock-O". There are plans to take these bands on tour in Mexico
column2: the United States and Europe.The city is also host to several dance and ballet companies such as the Chamber Ballet of Jalisco
column3: the Folkloric Ballet of the University of Guadalajara
column4: and University of Guadalajara Contemporary Ballet.

column1: The city is home to a renowned symphony orchestra. The Orquesta Filarmónica de Jalisco (Jalisco Philharmonic Orchestra) was founded by José Rolón in 1915. It held concerts from that time until 1924
column2: when state funding was lost. However
column3: the musicians kept playing to keep the orchestra alive. This eventually caught the attention of authorities and funding was restated in 1939. Private funding started in the 1940s and in 1950
column4: an organization called Conciertos Guadalajara A. C. was formed to continue fundraising for the orchestra. In 1971
column5: the orchestra became affiliated with the Department of Fine Arts of the State of Jalisco. The current name was adopted in 1988/ International soloists such as Paul Badura-Skoda
column6: Claudio Arrau
column7: Jörg Demus
column8: Henryck Szeryng
column11: Kurt Rydl and Alfred Brendel have performed with the organization. Today the orchestra is under the direction of Marco Parisotto.

column1: === Cuisine ===
Guadalajara has a wide variety of typical dishes
column2: such as pozole
column3: tamales
column4: sopes
column5: enchiladas
column6: tacos
column7: menudo (soup)
column8: carne en su jugo
column9: and frijoles charros. But one that totally sets it apart from the whole country is the "torta ahogada"
column10: which consists of a  salted birote (typical bread [tapatío]) smeared with refried beans
column11: with fried pork cut into pieces – also known as "carnitas" – all in sauce tomato seasoned with spices; it is also eaten accompanied by onions deflated in lemon and hot sauce; to drink
column12: it can be accompanied either with the famous tejuino – which is made with a base of sourdough corn
column13: accompanied by lemon ice cream – or with the tepache (made from the bark of fermented pineapple). The cuisine is a mix of pre-Hispanic and Spanish influences
column15: but dishes have their own flavors and are made with local techniques.

column1: Another typical meal of Guadalajara and the entire state of Jalisco is the "birria"
column2: which is usually made with either pork
column3: beef
column4: or goat. Handcrafted birria is made in a special oven
column5: which can be underground and covered with maguey leaves; the meat can be mixed with a tomato broth and spices
column6: or consumed separately. The traditional way of preparing birria is to pit roast the meat and spices wrapped in maguey leaves. It is served in bowls with minced onion
column7: limes and tortillas.

column1: Another typical dish of the tapatía kitchen is the carne en su jugo This dish consists of a beef broth with beans from the pot and is accompanied by bacon
column2: coriander
column3: onion and radish (sliced or whole). The dessert that is considered as a typical tapatío is the jericalla.

column1: When the Spanish conquistadors arrived in the Aztec empire
column2: a few religious ceremonies included eating pozole made with hominy and human flesh. This was the first type of pozole mentioned in Spanish writing
column3: as a ritual dish eaten only by select priests and noblemen. The meat from the thighs of slain enemy warriors was used. The Franciscan missionaries ended this custom when they banned Aztec religious ceremonies. The pozole in the local common cuisine was related to the ritual dish
column4: but prepared with turkey meat
column5: and later pork
column6: not with human flesh.

column1: Other dishes that are popular here include pozole
column2: a soup prepared with hominy
column3: pork or chicken
column4: topped with cabbage
column5: radishes
column6: minced onions and other condiments; pipián
column7: which is a sauce prepared with peanuts
column8: squash and sesame seed

column1: Jericallas are a typical Guadalajara dessert that is similar to flan
column2: that was created to give children proper nutrients while being delicious. It is made with eggs
column3: milk
column4: sugar
column5: vanilla and cinnamon
column6: and baked in the oven where it is broiled to the point that a burnt layer is produced. The burnt layer at the surface is what makes this dessert special and delicious.One of the drinks that is popular in Guadalajara is Tejuino
column7: a refreshing drink that contains a corn fermented base with sugarcane
column8: lime
column9: salt and chili powder.The city hosts the Feria Internacional Gastronomía (International Gastronomy Fair) each year in September showcasing Mexican and international cuisines. Many restaurants
column11: bakeries and cafés participate as well as producers of beer

column1: === Sports ===
Guadalajara is home to four professional football teams; Guadalajara
column2: also known as Chivas
column3: Atlas
column4: C.D. Oro and Universidad de Guadalajara. Guadalajara is the most successful and the most followed club in the country
column5: They have won the Mexican Primera División a total of 12 times
column6: and have won the Copa MX four times. In 2017 Chivas became the first team in Mexican football history to win a Double (a league and cup title) in a single season on two different occasions and their first since the since the 1969–70 season. Chivas went on to win the 2018 CONCACAF Champions League final against Major League Soccer side Toronto FC
column7: the second time they have won the torunament. Chivas won the first ever CONCACAF Champions League and are the only Guadalajara-based football team to win the tournament. Atlas also plays in the Mexican Primera División. They are known in the country as 'The Academy'
column8: hence they have provided Mexico's finest football players
column11: Pável Pardo
column13: and from "Chivas"
column15: and Mexico national team's former top scorer Jared Borgetti from Atlas. Atlas also won several Championships on Amateur Tournaments
column16: and first Football Championship of a Guadalajara Team back in 1951. They have not won any more first division championships since. Estudiantes was associated with the Universidad Autónoma de Guadalajara A.C.. It played in the Primera División
column17: with home games in the Estadio 3 de Marzo (March 3 Stadium
column18: for the University's 1935 date of founding). They've won also a single Championship back in 1994 as they defeated Santos. The team moved to Zacatecas and became the Mineros de Zacatecas in May 2014.

column1: Starting in October 2014
column2: Guadalajara rejoined the Liga Mexicana del Pacífico baseball tournament with the Charros de Jalisco franchise in play at the Athletic Stadium. Charreada
column3: the Mexican form of rodeo and closely tied to mariachi music
column4: is popular here. The biggest place for Charreada competitions
column5: the VFG Arena
column6: is located near the Guadalajara Airport founded by singer Vicente Fernández. Every September 15
column7: charros make a parade in the downtown streets to celebrate the Charro and Mariachi Day.Guadalajara hosted the 2011 Pan American Games. Since winning the bid to host the Games
column8: the city had been undergoing extensive renovations. The games brought in more than 5
column9: 000 athletes from approximately 42 countries from the Americas and the Caribbean. Sports included aquatics
column11: racquetball and 27 more
column12: with six others being considered. COPAG (the Organizing Committee for the Pan American Games Guadalajara 2011) had a total budget of US$250 million with the aim of updating the city's sports and general infrastructure. The center of the city was repaved and new hotels were constructed for the approximately 22
column13: 000 rooms that were needed in 2011. The new bus rapid transit (BRT) system
column15: was launched in March and runs along Avenida Independencia. The Pan-American village was built around the Bajio Zone. After the Games
column16: the buildings will be used for housing. There are already 13 existing venues in Guadalajara that the games will use
column19: and the UAG Gymnasium. Eleven new sporting facilities were created for the event. Other works included a second terminal in the airport
column20: a highway to Puerto Vallarta and a bypass for the southern part of the city.Lorena Ochoa
column21: a retired and former #1 female golfer
column22: Formula One driver Sergio Pérez who drives for Racing Point F1 Team and Javier "Chicharito" Hernández
column23: a forward who currently plays for LA Galaxy and the Mexico national team were also born in the city.

column1: == Government ==
As the capital of the state
column2: the city is the seat of the state's government. As a result
column3: state politics have a heavy influence in local decision-making and vice versa. Historically
column4: the mayorship of the city has been a common leaping platform for the state governorship. Additionally
column5: because of the sheer size of the Guadalajara Metropolitan Area vis-à-vis the rest of the state
column6: the city's urban agglomeration—largely dominated and coordinated by the Guadalajara city council—captures 12 of the 20 seats in the state legislature allocated by district.

column1: All three branches of the state government are concentrated around the historic city center
column2: with the Palace of Government
column3: seat of the state executive
column4: immediately southeast of the Cathedral. North
column5: across the Plaza de la Liberación
column6: is the State Legislature Building
column7: and immediately east of the latter is the Supreme Tribunal of State Justice.

column1: Like other municipalities in Mexico
column2: Guadalajara is governed by a municipal president
column3: who exercises executive power for three consecutive years. This office is currently occupied by Enrique Alfaro (Movimiento Ciudadano).

column1: The legislature has the cabildo
column2: formed by the form chosen by the candidate for mayor
column3: made up of aldermen
column4: who are not elected by the people by direct or indirect voting
column5: but the return happens automatically if the mayor wins.

column1: The municipality is divided into five electoral districts for the purpose of election of representatives of the city in the federal legislature. These districts are the VIII
column2: IX
column3: XI
column4: XIII and XIV of the state of Jalisco.

column1: The city and the municipality of Guadalajara are essentially co extensive with over 99% of the municipality living within the city limits and nearly all of the municipality urbanized. Urbanization centered on the city spreads out over seven other municipalities; of Zapopan
column2: Tlaquepaque
column3: Tonalá
column4: Tlajomulco de Zuñiga
column5: El Salto
column6: Ixtlahuacán de los Membrillos and Juanacatlán.These areas form the "Guadalajara Metropolitan Area" (Zona Metropolitana de Guadalajara in Spanish)
column7: which is the most populous in the state of Jalisco and the second most populous in the country after the Mexico City Metropolitan area. This metropolitan area had a population of 4

column1: == Education ==
Guadalajara is an important hub for higher education in both Mexico and Latin America
column2: as the home to numerous nationally and internationally ranked universities and research centers.

column1: The most important is the University of Guadalajara
column2: which was established on October 12
column4: by royal decree. The entity underwent a number of reorganizations since then
column5: but the modern university as it exists today was established in 1925
column6: when the governor of Jalisco convened professors
column7: students and others to re-establish the university. These precepts were organized into a law called the "Ley Organica". It was ranked fifth among the best Mexican universities in 2012.

column1: Guadalajara is home to Universidad Autónoma de Guadalajara (UAG)
column2: which was founded in 1935 and is the oldest private university in Mexico
column3: and Universidad del Valle de Atemajac (UNIVA)
column4: and the Western Institute of Technology and Higher Education.

column1: The city hosts campuses of several private schools
column2: including:

column1: Universidad Panamericana
Universidad La Salle
ITESO
Monterrey Institute of Technology
Guadalajara Metropolitan Technological University
Universidad del Valle de México
Universidad Marista de Guadalajara
Universidad Tecnológica de Guadalajara
Universidad del Valle de AtemajacIn addition
column2: the city hosts numerous international schools
column3: including:

column1: American School Foundation of Guadalajara (ASFG)
Lycée Français de Guadalajara
Colegio Alemán de Guadalajara
== Transportation ==
Guadalajara is well connected by a number of modern highways. These include Fed 15D
column2: which connects the city northwestward to Nogales
column3: Sonora
column4: via Tepic
column5: Nayarit and eastwards to Mexico City via Morelia; Fed 80D which runs northwest toward Aguascalientes; and Fed 54D which runs southward to the coast via Colima. The city's well connected transportation infrastructure allows easy access to Mexico City
column6: to the northwest and to the major beach resorts of Manzanillo
column7: Mazatlán and Puerto Vallarta to the southwest
column8: northwest

column1: The Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla Guadalajara International Airport
column2: also known as Guadalajara International Airport (ICAO code: MMGL) opened in 1966. It is located 16 km (10 mi) south of downtown Guadalajara
column3: and it was built on the Tlajomulco de Zuñiga city
column4: near Chapala. The airport is the third most active in the country (after Mexico City and Cancún) with direct flights to many Mexican and American cities.Within the city itself
column5: there are many forms of public transportation. The Guadalajara light rail/metro system
column6: named SITEUR (Sistema de Tren Eléctrico Urbano)
column7: Spanish for Urban Electrical Train System
column8: provides rapid transit service within Guadalajara and the neighboring municipalities of Zapopan and Tlaquepaque. It consists of two lines: line 1
column11: and line 2
column12: running from downtown to the east
column13: with 10 stations. The trains are electric and have a top speed of 70 km/h (43 mph). The 48 articulated cars currently in service were built in Mexico by Concarril/Bombardier. Construction on a third line began in 2014. Line 3 will run from Zapopan

column1: The Guadalajara Macrobús is a public transportation system based on the concept of bus rapid transit
column2: where each bus has a single route and boarding station. Phase I of the Macrobús project opened in 2009 with a 16-kilometre-long (9.9 mi) corridor following Calzada Independencia and serving 27 stations. The Guadalajara trolleybus system has been operating since the 1970s
column4: along with many city buses run by private companies and a bustling network of pedestrianised streets.

column1: Mi Bici Pública
column2: PBSC Urban Solutions-based public bike share system
column3: was launched in 2014. In 2016
column4: the city implemented 242 docking stations and 2116 bikes. As of September 2018 Mi Bici has 19
column5: 664 annually subscribed users.In Guadalajara
column6: a person spends an average of 82 minutes per weekday commuting with public transportation. 23% of public transit riders
column7: ride for more than 2 hours every day. The average amount of time people wait at a stop or station for public transit is 15 min
column8: while 22% of riders wait for an average of over 20 minutes each day. The average distance people usually ride in a single trip with public transit is 8 km
column9: and 16% travel for over 12 km in a single direction.
